posts.title: Getting Started with Next.js and TypeScript
posts.html:
Next.js has become one of the most popular React frameworks for building modern web applications. In this comprehensive guide, we'll explore how to set up a new Next.js project with TypeScript.

Why Next.js?

Next.js provides several benefits out of the box:

  • Server-side rendering (SSR)
  • Static site generation (SSG)
  • API routes
  • Automatic code splitting
  • Built-in CSS support

Setting Up the Project

Let's start by creating a new Next.js project with TypeScript support:

npx create-next-app@latest my-app --typescript
cd my-app
npm run dev

This command will create a new Next.js application with TypeScript configuration already set up.

Project Structure

The generated project will have the following structure:

my-app/
├── pages/
│   ├── api/
│   ├── _app.tsx
│   └── index.tsx
├── public/
├── styles/
├── next.config.js
├── package.json
└── tsconfig.json

Note: Make sure you have Node.js 14.6.0 or newer installed on your system.

For more advanced configurations, check out the official Next.js documentation.
posts.plaintext: Next.js has become one of the most popular React frameworks for building modern web applications. In this comprehensive guide, we'll explore how to set up a new Next.js project with TypeScript.
posts.custom_excerpt: Learn how to set up a Next.js project with TypeScript and explore the key features that make Next.js a powerful React framework.
